By Lisa Shock on Wednesday, October 24, 2001 - 09:57 pm:

I am not certain anyone has looked into it in detail. Each area has such different drills, that right now, I tend to chose simply based upon the stats I am interested in raising, and the ones I don't mind going down. I have noticed that some subs seem to find food they like better or is more nutritous in some areas, but I have not noticed a trend towards breeds doing better stat wise in drills by area. There are so many variables! I will keep it in mind, though.

By torey_luvullo on Thursday, October 25, 2001 - 04:23 am:

someone may well get interested in doing what you suggest; but someone may not either. the only sure thing is if someone does it, and posts the results, we will thank them.

By Varthlokkur on Thursday, October 25, 2001 - 05:03 am:

I have not noticed any particular area increasing a particular stat. Only the combination of monster and area benefiting a stat (ex: Marsala in Takrama training Defense).

One interesting note, and this may have been covered elsewhere, is to change areas to train up one stat and drop another.

For example, in Takrama, Rock Push raises Power but drops Intelligence. In Kalaragi, Dive raises Defense but drops Intelligence.

So, for my Marsala, whom Intelligence is not that important ATM, I can use those two areas to raise two of his best stats while lowering one I find insignificant. Now, this does not take into effect how an area may take into effect the stat gain of a particular monster. The negatives may outweigh the positives in this matter.

By Nate Railsback on Thursday, October 25, 2001 - 07:06 pm:

I always try to train my monsters in the area they match, not the area where the "best drills" are. I tried to raise a Scissor (Goat breed of Beaklon) in Kalaragi and it went horribly (my raising style kept pulling towards Hard). He's now not even three years old and is getting stat gains like an old man. I'll never repeat that mistake again.

By John Hawley on Thursday, October 25, 2001 - 07:16 pm:

One of the in-game messages from Mosha is that there are certain areas that certain monsters just won't train well in. Farns and NightFlyers, for instance, like Kalaragi, Morx and really like Takrama, but only do acceptably in Brillia.

By danz on Thursday, October 25, 2001 - 08:41 pm:

By Varthlokkur on Friday, October 26, 2001 - 04:55 am:

Well, I will vouch for Farns in Takrama. Valkyries, too, for that matter. Both breeds did quite well in the Takrama.

By John Hawley on Friday, October 26, 2001 - 04:57 am:

By watching the gains and losses, so far. I've not had anything just refuse to train in an area yet, but I'm only twenty-two years in. But areas that are good to train in, your monster will have good gains in the major and minor stats and minimal losses in the reducing stat, example: up 20, up 10, down 2. This marks good areas for me. Areas where you get 16-18 up, 9-11 up and 5 down would seem to me to be areas where they don't like to train. Also, like Nate, raising style tends toward Harder or Hard instead of Normal. More research is needed to see if there really are areas some monsters won't train in. I raised a Golem in Takrama and couldn't stay away from Hard, but Daruma Rock is just too good for a Golem to pass up.

By Varthlokkur on Friday, October 26, 2001 - 05:02 am:

By Nate Railsback on Saturday, October 27, 2001 - 09:00 pm:

I think we should look beyond basic breeds towards overall trends. Let me start, and everyone chime in with their comparable or contrasting experiences:

*Goat-types work well in Brillia, but not in Kalaragi.

*Morx-types work well in Kalaragi, but only average in Takrama.

By Adam Cochran on Friday, November 9, 2001 - 12:58 am:

I think it comes down to a pair of factors that make certain regions more compatible: Heat and Moisture.

Goat for example has really High Moisture and mid (probably) temperature.

Kalaragi has high temperature and high moisture.

Brillia has probably mid to high moisture, and really low temperature.

Morx is probably mid temperature and moisture.

Takrama is almost certainly high temp and low moisture.

Creatures native to those areas are naturally adapted to those conditions. They are comfortable in areas with closer conditions.
A creature from Goat would probably handle brilla or kalaragi well, but have trouble in Takrama.
A creature from Morx should handle any place averagely.
A creature from Takrama would probably feel more at home in Kalaragi than Goat because of the presumably closer temperature.
And of course characteristics modify all this.

By Nate Railsback on Friday, November 9, 2001 - 04:07 pm:

That's what I used to think. But then my Scissor (Beaklon/Goat) did horribly in Kalaragi, which logically would be a good match for it. My Fukazo (Suezo/Goat) did great in Brillia, which might be an okay match for it, but my pure Zan (Brillia-type) did lackluster in Goat, so the reverse doesn't seem to be true. My Kyuza (Henger/Morx) did fair in Takrama, but great in Kalaragi.

Also, my Ogyo (Goat-type) did absolutely horribly in Morx when I first started the game, and now that I've had a chance to raise her in Goat she's doing moderately acceptable.

Well, in any case I'll be trying out more of this when I raise my Pancho, who's slated (har!) to inherit my Ogyo's heart when she passes on.
